title: Devoted Tesco worker collapsed and died 30 minutes after confronting shoplifter
text:

A "well respected" Tesco worker who had never had a day off sick in 18 years collapsed and died shortly after confronting a shoplifter, an inquest heard.

Mum-of-two Hilary Simmons challenged the thieves at the Tesco Express branch in Middlesbrough 30 minutes before telling a colleague “I feel like I’m going to have a heart attack".

A jury inquest, held at Teesside Coroner's Court heard she had worked at the store since it opened 18 years ago and had never called in sick.

But within half an hour of the incident on April 30 last year, the 59-year-old collapsed while having a cigarette with a work colleague.

(Image: Evening Gazette)

She later died at James Cook University Hospital in Middlesbrough.

The inquest was told Mrs Simmons had “severe” heart disease which was undiagnosed and that the stress of the incident had contributed to her death, but not to a criminal standard.

Four arrests were made after Mrs Simmons' death as part of a manslaughter investigation but all were later released and the police investigation was closed in May.

Jurors heard after the confrontation Mrs Simmons was “shaken and felt unwell” and at one point she was heard to say: “I feel like I’m going to have a heart attack".

Her husband Stan, went to visit her at the A&E department of the hospital after being told his wife had been “taken ill.”

Tragically, he was told by doctors that “she could not be saved".

In a statement, which was read out at court, Mr Simmons said his wife had worked for Tesco for 18 years and at the Corporation Road shop since it opened.

“She never had a day off work sick”, he said.

Telling the inquest she was well thought of, he said staff called her “Tesco mummy.”

“She knew all of the shoplifters and must have stopped hundreds in her time," he continued.

“She was well known and well respected in town.

“No one had a bad word to say about her.”

The family believed she had no known illness and was on no medication.

(Image: Evening Gazette)

A post mortem found that Mrs Simmons had no significant medical history but died “as a result of heart disease."

The inquest was told that due to the severity of her heart disease, she could have succumbed to “sudden death” at any moment.

The post mortem said that death is more likely “after a period of stress.”

The inquest heard Mrs Simmons was “angry and frustrated” after the confrontation.

The post mortem added that the “incident as a whole has contributed significantly to the development of arithmea and her death.”

A second post mortem said the “altercation contributed (to her death) but not to the criminal standards mark.”

CCTV of the incident was also shown to the jury.

It showed two men enter the store and then leave a short time later, with Hilary and another staff member following them.

The jury was told that Mrs Simmons was later seen sitting outside the shop with a cigarette and her “head in her hands”.

She vomited and a Big Issue seller brought her a bottle of water while other staff members attended to her and called for the emergency services.

The inquest heard Michael James Love stole a bottle of wine from the store and was caught by Mrs Simmons.

The confrontation ended after Mr Love, who was previously banned for stealing, and a friend left the store.

(Image: Evening Gazette)

Mr Love, who was found guilty of theft, admitted he stole a bottle of wine from the store, but also claimed Hilary had shouted verbal abuse and "pushed and shoved" him in the chest. He denied pushing her.

Giving evidence at the inquest, Mr Love, who was originally questioned in connection over alleged manslaughter, claimed that Mrs Simmons began shouting at him and his friend, and calling them offensive terms.

He said he did deny stealing goods to her and said she "pushed and shoved him in chest."

He denied pushing her but maintained she "hit" him and said he then walked away from the shop and "drank the bottle of wine."

"She wouldn't let me leave the shop, she was standing in front of me", Mr Love said.

He admitted at the inquest that he had previously been "barred" from the shop for stealing but that he thought the ban had expired when he went back.

But Mr Butt accused Mr Love of lying, and CCTV which the jury viewed did not show Mrs Simmons obstructing or hitting Mr Love during the confrontation.

A colleague of Mrs Simmons, who had been working at the store for three months, also gave evidence at the inquest.

She said her colleague had alerted her about the two men who had walked in.

She said Mr Love was "using his height" to intimidate 5ft 2in Hilary after he was confronted.

She went on to say that Mrs Simmons had experience of confronting shoplifters and "took it personally" when people stole from the shop.

"Hilary wanted him to return whatever he had taken", she said.

"It was like someone had stolen from her home, it affected her a lot.

"She took a lot of pride in her job."

She also denied that Mrs Simmons had hurled abuse at Mr Love.

"I never heard her use that word. It's not something that she would say.

"She never made contact with any of them. She was fed up with them coming in and out of the shop taking what they like when they like."

Tesco has since made changes in the store, with a full-time security guard now on duty and staff have also received further training.

Matthew Butt, who was appearing on behalf of Tesco, said the company offered their "deep condolences" to her family and called her a "valued colleague and friend."

The inquest is expected to last two or three days.
description: Hilary Simmons had never had a day off sick in 18 years, since she started working at the branch in Middlesbrough
